description:
Arthrobacter ramosus is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Arthrobacter. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. Arthrobacter ramosus is characterized by its ability to form branched filaments and rods, which is a distinctive feature of the genus Arthrobacter.

This bacterium is commonly found in soil and other environmental samples, where it plays a role in the decomposition of organic matter. Arthrobacter ramosus is known for its metabolic versatility, as it can utilize a wide range of carbon sources for energy and growth.

Scientifically, Arthrobacter ramosus is classified within the phylum Actinobacteria, which is a group of high-GC, Gram-positive bacteria known for their diverse metabolic capabilities and ecological importance. The species was first isolated and described in the 1960s, and it has been the subject of various studies on its potential applications in bioremediation, biodegradation, and other areas of environmental biotechnology.
